name: Kate R&D Lock
description: Lots of card draw, strong economy and a toolbox of programs to set up big R&D pressure throughout the early/midgame and allow damaging The Maker's Eyes later in the game.

name: Weyland Tag n' Bag
description:
Posted Bounties have now become Veterans Programs since the Store Champs

This deck is pretty standard Weyland, looking to force through a SEA Source-double scorched play at some point in the game. The key to beating Plascrete in the lategame is bluffing out a Snare! and forcing the runner to run it. In order to accomplish this, you have to score at least 2-3 points in smaller agendas before playing out the Snare! in a remote server, and choose a point in the game where the runner does not have the resources on board to get through your server but you think they have a card that will get them through in their hand (Inside Job, Sure Gamble, or anything else that will make them think they've ruined your maths).

It is unlikely that a runner will run on their last click, but most will run on the second or third click, not allowing them to get back up to four cards if they choose to remove the tag from Snare! (which they have to not to die to triple Scorched).

Otherwise, if they don't have Plascrete, winning is just about using Jackson and Green Level to draw into combo pieces, and the smaller ICE to protect your centrals long enough for you to assemble it. Lots of the ICE can be scored behind if they're playing cautiously, and even if they manage to get through, you can usually drain their economy more than yours is depleted during runs, allowing you to get closer to the credit advantage necessary to combo off.

name: You Snooze You Loose
description:
v8.1

With Curtain Wall / Archer + Oversight AI you can easily score an agenda or you can just catch the Runner in a trap, they won't expect that much Net dmg out of Weyland.

name: Leaking Accounts
description:
v3.9

Great credits/clicks ratio eco, arguably best ice-breakers = what else you need? Maybe something little annoying on the side, like John + Data Leak + Crash Space to spend 4 clicks and force the Corp trash 2 cards of their R&D. You can do this a couple of turns in a row if the Corp does not "force" you to run remote. Doing unsuccessful runs is quite alright.

name: I'm a BIG GIRl now!
description:
This deck is all about heavy Ice Breakers. See past the install cost and focus on the numbers. All these breakers cost almost nothing to use compared to other breakers, and will get you in almost everywhere with about 10 credits on you.

The key feature in this deck is Test Run. Your goal is to get that card as fast as possible, and to your aid you got Professional Contacts and Diesel. When you have it, use it together with Scavenge to lower the install cost of our 7-9 credit breakers. You will land on about 3-5 credits per breaker, and have the freedom to choose wich one. Same Old Thing makes the Test Run combos even easier to score.

At a first, the ecenomy can look a little on the low side, but once you have your Magnum Opus and Prof.Con up, you will never have to care about the money.

name: FlexiRig 1.0
description:
This deck is put together with flexibility in mind. It excels at having the ability to quickly pull out the programs that will get you through a server the cheapest and readjust your rig on the fly to pressure wherever the corp is weakest.

Economy is based based on Magnum Opus and Freelance Coding Contract with Sure Gamble and Modded for additional boost.

With that in mind the cards you're looking for in your opening hand are (in order of importance):

1) Magnum Opus and/or Freelance

2) Quality Time or Diesel

3) Modded

With a bit of luck this type of hand should allow you to finish your first turn with around 10 credits and possibly MO on the table (depending on other cards). If you are forced to play with a bad draw just try to land Magnum Opus, get some credits and regain your pacing. Although the corp will probably score an agenda while you're doing that.

From here on out continue drawing cards, installing the cheaper ones and Freelancing others. If you get Sharpshooter or Faerie you can do some exploratory runs the get a feel for the corps ice.

There is no fixed way to play this deck after that, the general idea is to start pushing where the corp is weakest. Most of the time you want to Test Run + Scavenge some big, annoying breakers to the table and run.

You will constantly want to adjust to what the corp is doing. For example:

  • R&D is weak? Install/Scavenge Medium or Keyhole.

  • Archives/HQ are weak? Install/Scavenge Sneakdoor and/or Nerve Agent.

  • Corp trying to score because you don't have a full rig - Install/Scavenge Femme or just switch icebreakers.

  • They play with low str code gates? Get Yog. Low str barriers? Get Battering Ram. Seeing Chum and/or Viper? Get Torch. And so on :)

Here are a few things to remember:

  • Test Run and Scavenge can be used to pull any program from the stack or the heap, not just icebreakers.

  • Same Old Thing is there to replace anything you need but don't have at the moment - Scavenge, Test Run, even Quality Time.

  • If the game drags out you can just Levy everything back to the stack and start again.

  • Djinn is a wonderful MU extending tool, you can host all kinds of useful stuff on it, like Magnum Opus, Keyhole, Sneakdoor. Play it if you manage to get it early

  • There is no defense against Scorched Earth in this deck so if you suspect the corp of playing a burn deck try to have a lot of credits to offset any traces they might pull (SEA Source, Counterstrike, Midseason)

  • If they're playing a lot of asset economy - deny it. You're rich enough for it.

Last but not least - try to be surprising and don't be afraid to scavenge icebreakers for ones you need to get in right now. This will catch many corp players off guard.

name: Chaotic Violence v02
description:
I tried to build a "big breaker" Deck using Chaos Theory. The basic idea is, of course, to get the big breakers into game quickly and free of cost and then be able to get in everywhere.

Most of the card choices are fairly obvious I believe, some were very tough choices, though.

As for Dinosaurus: I thought I'd rather have Dino in there for femme (MU and Strength boost), hoping that a strength 5 is not so credit consuming when having to eat through big ICE. This allows to leave out another Killer, too. Three femmes might be overkill, but once they are out they can reliably eat through problematic ICE.

Only the most urgent cards are include as three-ofs. Since there is a lot of card draw and I can go through the deck quite fast and there is also a Levy AR Access in there to start again cycling through the deck.

The rest is pretty standard fare I believe. The tests so far went very well (played 4 games), but this is my first deck and comments are much appreciated. Please be polite though, thanks! :-)

name: [Concept Deck] Central Abuse
description:
I'm toying with this whole "central only" build. Testing to see how viable a heavy central attack can be, and then building in a basic remote attack later.

Idea here is to burst up lots of cash early and get the rig out fast while being able to draw into heavy burst later as well. HQ and R&D interfaces make sure runs are productive, and all the money makes it easy to hit frequently. Opus keeps the cash flow going into the long game if R&D just won't give it up.

Can't attack the remote, sure, but R&D lock should be easy, and if the corp overdraws, HQ interface and easy entrance will help pluck them out of HQ.

name: Keyhole Kate - Szeged 03.01 3rd place
description: It was a True Colors tournament. Went undefeated with this runner deck.

name: Tag Floatting v2.2
description:
The goal of this deck is to be able to score agendas by attacking the weakest central server. Medium pressures R&D, Nerve Agent pressures HQ, and Data Leak Reverse pressures Archives. The deck as a whole is also designed to hurt the Corp's economy, in order to keep its resources protected and to make the early game lasts longer.

Key cards:

  • Reina Roja vs Whizzard is an eternal struggle; I'm constantly changing between both based on my expectation about the metagame I will meet;

  • Account Siphon + Vamp are the main economy control on this deck, they punish the Corp for not protecting HQ and they keep the resources safe;

  • Medium and Nerve Agent are pretty obvious, Medium is the strongest "R&D lock" in the game and it often wins the game by itself;

  • Data Leak Reverse forces the Corp to trash it a.s.a.p. and protect Archives at the same time, it is easily one of the most important cards in this deck;

Icebreakers:

  • Knight is the jack-of-all-trades;

  • Corroder is used to counter Paper Wall and Wraparound;

  • Mimic is used to "facecheck" safely;

  • Yog.0 is here just in case (it is almost useless, to be honest);

  • Emergency Shutdown is there as a contingency plan, in case the Corp manages to rez a piece of ICE that can't be broken easily (I know a lot of people don't like it, so you can use a 3rd Account Siphon if you wish);

  • Parasite, Datasucker and Deja Vu are used to trash any piece of ICE that cannot be broken, Parasite does a great job paired with Knight and Emergency Shutdown;

Economy:

  • Keep in mind that this deck doesn't require too much credits, as it controls the Corp economy too;

  • Sure Gamble doesn't require explanation, it is what it is;

  • Dirty Laundry is a influence-free Easy Mark that triggers John Masanori;

  • Armitage Codebusting is a countermeasure against Closed Accounts, and it is also the cheapest neutral economy card in the game - which is important in a deck with such poor economy;

  • Joshua B., in the worst case, works like a link-free Underworld Contact;

  • Spinal Modem provides MU when needed and also an economy boost;

  • Activist Support will almost never trigger, but scarying the Corp will often be more than enough to keep you ahead in the match;

Others:

  • Plascrete Carapace is there against Scorched Earth;

  • Clone Chip is used as a mid-run Parasite, but it can be an Scavenge if you like it better;

  • 2x John Masanori + 1x Quality Time is more than enough to keep your hand full of cards, I honestly have no idea why using 3x Quality Time is so popular nowadays.

name: Zombie Planet (Albany, NY) Store Championship 2014 1st Place
description: Nothing special except maybe the Ghost Branch and Neural Katana. Weyland T&B.

name: Zombie Planet (Albany, NY) Store Championship 2014 1st Place
description: Simple Noise Rara I guess. In the future, I'd cut hemorrhage (or put in more than 1) and surge.
